timeline.message:
Fix definingClass for StaticFieldVarHandle

For a StaticFieldVarHandle, definingClass should point to the owner of
the static field.
 
Example:
    public class P { public static String publicObject = "s"; }
    public class C extends P { }
    VarHandle vh =
    	MethodHandles.lookup()
    		.in(C.class)
    		.findStaticVarHandle(C.class, "publicObject", String.class);

In the above example, vh is an instance of StaticFieldVarHandle, which
extends FieldVarHandle. vh.definingClass should contain class P since it
defines the publicObject.

Currently, vh.definingClass is set to class C, which is not the owner of
the static field. This fix correctly sets the defining class for a
StaticFieldVarHandle.

Signed-off-by: Babneet Singh <sbabneet@ca.ibm.com>

Fix typo: StaticFieldViewVarHandle -> StaticFieldVarHandle

StaticFieldViewVarHandle is corrected to StaticFieldVarHandle.

Signed-off-by: Babneet Singh <sbabneet@ca.ibm.com>

Fix typo: StaticFieldViewVarHandle -> StaticFieldVarHandle

StaticFieldViewVarHandle is corrected to StaticFieldVarHandle.

Signed-off-by: Babneet Singh <sbabneet@ca.ibm.com>

Fix typo: StaticFieldViewVarHandle -> StaticFieldVarHandle

StaticFieldViewVarHandle is corrected to StaticFieldVarHandle.

Signed-off-by: Babneet Singh <sbabneet@ca.ibm.com>

Fix typo: StaticFieldViewVarHandle -> StaticFieldVarHandle

StaticFieldViewVarHandle is corrected to StaticFieldVarHandle.

Signed-off-by: Babneet Singh <sbabneet@ca.ibm.com>

timeline.bodyText:
Comments shouldn't be about the past - "no longer satisfies" - but explaining why is great!

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            	/* definingClass cannot be a final field since it no longer satisfies the conditions of
          
          
            
            	 * the final keyword. It is modified twice, once in Java code and once in native code.
          
          
            
            	 */
          
          
            
            	/* definingClass cannot be a final field since it is modified twice, once in 
          
          
            
            	 * Java code and once in native code.
          
          
            
            	 */
timeline.author: DanHeidinga

timeline.bodyText: Can this be broken into a series of tests?  It will be easier to focus debugging efforts in the future if we can clearly see which operation failed.
timeline.author: DanHeidinga

replies.bodyText: Divided into a series of tests.
replies.author: babsingh

timeline.message:
Fix definingClass for StaticFieldVarHandle

For a StaticFieldVarHandle, definingClass should point to the owner of
the static field.
 
Example:
    public class P { public static String publicObject = "s"; }
    public class C extends P { }
    VarHandle vh =
    	MethodHandles.lookup()
    		.in(C.class)
    		.findStaticVarHandle(C.class, "publicObject", String.class);

In the above example, vh is an instance of StaticFieldVarHandle, which
extends FieldVarHandle. vh.definingClass should contain class P since it
defines the publicObject.

Currently, vh.definingClass is set to class C, which is not the owner of
the static field. This fix correctly sets the defining class for a
StaticFieldVarHandle.

Signed-off-by: Babneet Singh <sbabneet@ca.ibm.com>

Add a new test case in StaticFieldVarHandleTests

The new test case verifies if StaticFieldVarHandle functions correctly
while accessing a static field of a parent class via a child class. It
only covers the reference value type. Existing test cases ensure that
StaticFieldVarHandle will behave correctly for other value types in a
similar scenario if the new test case for the reference value type
succeeds.

Signed-off-by: Babneet Singh <sbabneet@ca.ibm.com>

Fix typo: StaticFieldViewVarHandle -> StaticFieldVarHandle

StaticFieldViewVarHandle is corrected to StaticFieldVarHandle.

Signed-off-by: Babneet Singh <sbabneet@ca.ibm.com>
